entry.title: Cello Sonata (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Claude Debussy (pictured) described his Cello Sonata, composed within a few weeks in July 1915 at a Normandy seaside town, in a letter to his publisher Durand as of "almost classical form"?

entry.title: Royce Williams (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after U.S. Navy pilot Royce Williams engaged in a solo dogfight with seven Soviet MiG-15s during the Korean War, he was ordered never to tell anyone about it?

entry.title: Tomoi (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 1985 manga series Tomoi contains the first depiction of HIV/AIDS in any literary medium in Japan?

entry.title: Eunice Newton Foote (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the unacknowledged contributions of Eunice Newton Foote to climate change research were recovered by Elizabeth Wagner Reed, whose research in genetics were also obscured?

entry.title: sensory friendly (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that people with sensory processing disorders often require sensory friendly environments which are designed to accommodate their condition?

entry.title: Gilbert Eastman (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that American educator Gilbert Eastman, who acted in and wrote American Sign Language plays, won an Emmy Award in 1993?

entry.title: Huliya (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Nirmalendu Goon shared his doubts about Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's political decisions during the 1969 East Pakistan mass uprising in his poem Huliya?

entry.title: Chaz Stevens (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that after Florida schools banned 54 mathematics books, Chaz Stevens petitioned that they also ban the Bible?
